title.children: Human Rights Watch says blocking aid to Gaza, Israeli strikes could amount to war crimes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has reiterated a call for a "humanitarian pause" to deliver supplies to people in Gaza. "I again reiterate, Australia's call for humanitarian pauses on hostilities. We want humanitarian supplies of food, water, medicine, fuel to reach people in desperate need," she told reporters in Adelaide. Ms Wong said that while Israel has a right to defend itself, it also has an obligation to follow international law. "I've said that, in affirming our view, that Israel has a right to defend itself, Israel's friends including Australia have emphasised that the way Israel does that matters", she said. "We know that Hamas is a terrorist group, we know that it has burrowed itself into civilian infrastructure, we know that it's using civilians as a shield. We know that terrorism must be confronted. "All of these challenges do not lessen Israel's obligation to observe international law and the rules of war. Even in war, there are rules. "The international community will not accept ongoing civilian deaths."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wong calls for 'humanitarian pause', says Israel must follow 'rules of war'

children.content: "I again reiterate, Australia's call for humanitarian pauses on hostilities. We want humanitarian supplies of food, water, medicine, fuel to reach people in desperate need," she told reporters in Adelaide.
Ms Wong said that while Israel has a right to defend itself, it also has an obligation to follow international law.
"I've said that, in affirming our view, that Israel has a right to defend itself, Israel's friends including Australia have emphasised that the way Israel does that matters", she said.
"We know that Hamas is a terrorist group, we know that it has burrowed itself into civilian infrastructure, we know that it's using civilians as a shield. We know that terrorism must be confronted.
"All of these challenges do not lessen Israel's obligation to observe international law and the rules of war. Even in war, there are rules.
"The international community will not accept ongoing civilian deaths."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When asked about retired public school teacher Abdullah Dahlan, one of the Australians still stuck in Gaza, she said the Australian government is doing all they can to get remaining Australians and visa holders out. Mr Dahlan said he went to the border crossing but decided to go back into Gaza when Egyptian officials wouldn't let his wife Samah, a Palestinian with a visa for Australia, leave. "There area lot more Nationals to get out... we hope that the parties who have broken this arrangement can continue to assure passage for civilians out of Gaza will continue to do what we can to press for that, obviously, as I said, the numbers are substantial but I can assure Australians and all of the Australians who worried about those relatives, friends in Gaza that we will continue to press for Australians to have safe passage," she says. "I assume he is registered with us and we are in contact with, as much as we are able to." "Communications have been disrupted at times and difficult circumstances but we are in contact with all the Australians who are registered and we are seeking to assist all of those who wish to leave."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Efforts underway to get remaining Australians out says Wong

children.content: When asked about retired public school teacher Abdullah Dahlan,
one of the Australians still stuck in Gaza
, she said the Australian government is doing all they can to get remaining Australians and visa holders out.
Mr Dahlan said he went to the border crossing but decided to go back into Gaza when Egyptian officials wouldn't let his wife Samah, a Palestinian with a visa for Australia, leave.

"There area lot more Nationals to get out... we hope that the parties who have broken this arrangement can continue to assure passage for civilians out of Gaza will continue to do what we can to press for that, obviously, as I said, the numbers are substantial but I can assure Australians and all of the Australians who worried about those relatives, friends in Gaza that we will continue to press for Australians to have safe passage," she says.
"I assume he is registered with us and we are in contact with, as much as we are able to."

"Communications have been disrupted at times and difficult circumstances but we are in contact with all the Australians who are registered and we are seeking to assist all of those who wish to leave."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister of Foreign Affairs Penny Wong has just spoken to reporters in Adelaide about the situation in Gaza and the Australians who are wanting to return home. Ms Wong said she has spoken with the Australian ambassador to Cairo who confirmed that the Australians who have made it there are in good health. "I'm so relieved and grateful this cohort was able to cross. They have been supported by a staff in Egypt, transborder to Cairo and travel arrangements are being made for them to get home free of charge," she said. The ambassador confirmed there were children among the cohort of people who left Gaza among some the first foreign nationals to cross the border through Rafah. "I could hear children in the background and I said to him, are there kids? And he said yes, some of the Australian children who made it to Cairo today," Ms Wong said. "They had a seven journey which is pretty tiring. I asked about the health of all the Australians, he said that people seemed in good health and were relieved but we are insuring anyone who needs medical attention will receive it. " Ms Wong thanked DFAT staff and other Australian agencies for their work in Canberra and on the ground in Egypt and Israel in contributing to the outcome. She also thanked her counterparts in Egypt, Qatar Israel and the US for brokering the arrangement. The work continues to bring the remaining Australians, perfmanent residents and their families home, she said. "I know how distressing the situation is for them and for their next of kin. Please be sure, we will continue to press for all of you to cross the border in Gaza, we will continue to do what we've been doing for the last few weeks which is to engage with all that we can to ensure safe passage."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians who left Gaza are in good health: Penny Wong

cross the border in Gaza, we will continue to do what we've been doing for the last few weeks which is to engage with all that we can to ensure safe passage."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Federal Court has granted an interim injunction that prevents Santos from starting work on a gas pipeline in waters of Northern Australia. The order means work to lay the Barossa gas export pipeline can't start. The order comes after group Environmental Defenders Office, on behalf of Indigenous groups, urged the injunction. The indigenous group on the Tiwi Islands allege the pipeline would impact their cultural heritage. Santos says an independent anthropologist concluded there we no underwater cultural heritage places. You can read more about the issue in the article by colleague Emilia Terzon that I've posted below. The court will sit again on November 13 to determine whether to extend the injunction. Santos shares are 2.3% lower today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Santos prevented  from starting work on gas pipeline in waters off Tiwi Islands

featuredLink.title: These Tiwi elders believe burial grounds are under threat from a gas pipeline. The company says they don't exist

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The best performer on the ASX 200 today is lithium producer Sayona Mining. The company is listed here, but most of its assets are in Canada. Today, it announced to the ASX it has found multiple high-grade lithium intercepts from a recent round of drilling at its North American Lithium (NAL) project in Quebec. Quick explainer for anyone who's not familiar with mining: When companies have a site of land they want to explore to find out what they have in the ground and how good it is, they send gigantic drills hundreds of metres — even up to a thousand — into the earth to retrieve drill or core samples. The drills churn out long poles of earth, that are then cut up into smaller pieces and assessed for their quality of whatever the mineral the company is looking for. So the team at Sayona have assessed the results of 57 drill holes (giving them 14.3km worth of sample to look at!) and they like what they see. The boss of Sayona, James Brown said in a statement to the stock exchange that the results mean a potential upgrade of what they have at their site. "Some of the intercepts from this recent drilling program are thicker and higher grade than any previously encountered, increasing confidence in NAL's mine life." I'll just add here, the company's share price is significantly lower than the start of the year - it was about $0.30 at the end of January - so it's still a long way off that figure. Today it's worth about $0.08 a share.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lithium producer soars on drilling results

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shares in Origin keep edging lower today. They're off more than six per cent to about $8.50 a share. That's after a Brookfield and EIG-led consortium increased their offer to about $9.53 a share for the Australian energy producer. The bidders say it's an 8% increase on their previous offer of $8.81 and a 70% premium to Origin's share price a year ago, before the takeover speculation began. The bid was increased after some major shareholders had indicated they would reject the previous offer. Origin's board is recommending shareholders vote in favour of the deal. But Origin's largest shareholder, AustralianSuper, says the offer remains "substantially below" its estimate of Origin's long-term value. AustralianSuper manages $300bn in assets. Analysts say if AustralianSuper says no, the deal needs work. "If Australian Super is rejecting it, the likelihood of the deal going ahead is very low," said Jamie Hannah, deputy head of investments and capital markets at VanEck, which owns a 0.3 per cent stake in Origin. "I think the deal is back at the drawing board at the moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy extends losses as AustralianSuper says 'no'
